  "article_text": [
    "a _ toric integrable system _ @xmath0 is an integrable system on a connected symplectic @xmath1-dimensional manifold @xmath2 in which all the flows generated by the @xmath3 , @xmath4 , are periodic of a fixed period .",
    "that is , there is a hamiltonian action of a torus @xmath5 of dimension @xmath6 on @xmath7 with momentum map @xmath8 .",
    "we will assume that this action is effective and that @xmath7 is compact .",
    "in this case , the quadruple @xmath9 is often called a _ symplectic toric manifold _ of dimension @xmath1 , to emphasize the connection with toric varieties ( in fact , all symplectic toric manifolds are toric varieties , e.g. , see remark [ de ] and @xcite ) .    the goal of the paper is to construct natural topologies on moduli spaces of compact symplectic toric @xmath10-manifolds under natural equivalence relations and study some of their basic topological properties .    throughout most of this paper",
    ", we will assume that @xmath11 , but several definitions and statements hold in more generality .",
    "let , throughout this paper , @xmath12 denote the @xmath6-dimensional standard torus @xmath13 i.e. , the cartesian product of @xmath6 copies of the circle @xmath14 equipped with the product operation .",
    "denote by @xmath15 the lie algebra @xmath16 of @xmath5 and by @xmath17 the dual of @xmath15 .",
    "strictly speaking , the momentum map @xmath8 of the hamiltonian action of @xmath18 on a manifold @xmath7 is a map @xmath19 .",
    "however , the presentation is simpler , if from the beginning we consider this map as a map @xmath20 . how to do this is a standard , but not canonical , procedure .",
    "choose an epimorphism @xmath21 , for instance , @xmath22 .",
    "this lie group epimorphism has discrete center @xmath23 and the inverse of the corresponding lie algebra isomorphism is given by @xmath24 .",
    "thus , for @xmath25 , we get the non - canonical isomorphism between the corresponding commutative lie algebras @xmath26 where @xmath27 is the @xmath28 element in the canonical basis of @xmath29 . choosing an inner product @xmath30 on @xmath15",
    ", we obtain an isomorphism @xmath31 , and hence taking its inverse and composing it with the isomorphism @xmath32 described above , we get an isomorphism @xmath33 . in this way , we obtain a momentum map @xmath34 .",
    "if @xmath35 is a symplectic manifold , denote by @xmath36 the group of symplectic diffeomorphisms of @xmath7 .      with the conventions in section [ conventions ] , where @xmath5 and the identification @xmath38 are _ fixed _",
    ", we next define the moduli space of toric manifolds .",
    "let @xmath39 and @xmath40 be symplectic toric manifolds , with effective symplectic actions @xmath41 and @xmath42 .",
    "these two symplectic toric manifolds are _ isomorphic _ if there exists an equivariant symplectomorphism @xmath43 ( i.e. , @xmath44 is a diffeomorphism satisfying @xmath45 which intertwines the @xmath5 actions ) such that @xmath46 ( see also ( * ? ? ? *",
    "definition i.1.16 ) ) .",
    "we denote by @xmath47 the _ moduli space _ ( the set of equivalence classes ) of @xmath1-dimensional symplectic toric manifolds under this equivalence relation .",
    "the motivation for introducing this moduli space comes from the following seminal result , due to delzant @xcite .",
    "[ del1 ] let @xmath48 and @xmath49 be two toric symplectic manifolds .",
    "if @xmath50 then there exists an equivariant symplectomorphism @xmath51 such that the following diagram @xmath52_-{\\mu } \\ar[r]^-{\\varphi } & ( m',{\\omega } ' ) \\ar[d]^-{\\mu ' } \\\\",
    "\\mu(m ) \\ar[r]^-{\\text{id } } & \\mu'(m')}\\ ] ] commutes .",
    "the convexity theorem of atiyah @xcite and guillemin - sternberg @xcite asserts that the image of the momentum map is a convex polytope .",
    "in addition , if the action is toric ( the acting torus is precisely half the dimension of the manifold ) the momentum image is a delzant polytope ( see section [ sec : dp ] ) .",
    "let @xmath53 denote the set of delzant polytopes .",
    "as a consequence of theorem [ del1 ] , the following map @xmath54 \\ni \\mathcal{m}_\\mathbb{t } \\longmapsto \\mu(m ) \\in \\mathcal{d}_\\mathbb{t},\\ ] ] is an injection . however , delzant also shows how from a delzant polytope it is possible to reconstruct a symplectic toric manifold , thus implying that is a _",
    "bijection_.    to simplify notations , we usually write @xmath48 identifying the representative with its equivalence class @xmath55 $ ] in @xmath56 .    if we choose a different identification @xmath57 in section [ conventions ] , then the resulting moduli space @xmath58 is , in general , a set _ different _ from @xmath59 .",
    "however , @xmath37 and @xmath58 are in bijective correspondence by a map which preserves the structures that this paper deals with ( section [ top ] ) .",
    "an alternative and equivalent approach to this convention is to define @xmath60 to be a space of pairs , where the second element of the pair involves the lie algebra identification .",
    "we shall use the first convention throughout the paper ( see section [ stm ] ) .",
    "note that for every non - zero @xmath61 the equivalence class of @xmath48 is different from that of @xmath62 .",
    "we distinguish these two spaces since for general hamiltonian @xmath63-actions the constant @xmath64 is an important element of @xmath65 .",
    "indeed , given a connected lie group @xmath63 and a hamiltonian @xmath63-space @xmath66 with moment map @xmath67 , if @xmath68 is a different choice of moment map for the @xmath63-action then @xmath69 ^ 0\\subset \\mathfrak{g}^*$ ] , the annihilator of the commutator ideal of @xmath70 , which coincides with @xmath71 , the first lie algebra cohomology group ( see for example ( * ? ? ?",
    "* @xmath72 ) ) .",
    "following @xcite , we say that two symplectic toric manifolds @xmath48 and @xmath74 are _ weakly isomorphic _ if there exists an automorphism of the torus @xmath75 and an @xmath76-equivariant symplectomorphism @xmath43 , i.e. , the following diagram commutes : @xmath77^{\\;\\;\\rho^ * } \\ar[d]_{(h,\\varphi ) } & m   \\ar[d]_{\\varphi } \\\\ { { \\mathbb t}}\\times m ' \\;\\;\\ar[r]^{\\;\\;\\rho'^ * } &   m ' ,   } \\ ] ] where @xmath78 for all @xmath79 , @xmath80 , and similarly for @xmath81 .",
    "we denote by @xmath73 the _ moduli space of weakly isomorphic @xmath1-dimensional symplectic toric manifolds _ ( see section [ stm ] for more details ) .",
    "two weakly isomorphic toric manifolds @xmath48 and @xmath74 are isomorphic if and only if @xmath76 in ( [ comm action1 ] ) is the identity and @xmath82 .",
    "we consider the space of delzant polytopes @xmath83 and turn it into a metric space by endowing it with the distance function given by the volume of the symmetric difference @xmath84 of any two polytopes .",
    "the map ( [ map ] ) allows us to define a metric @xmath85 on @xmath37 as the pullback of the metric defined on @xmath83 , thereby getting the metric space @xmath86 .",
    "_ this metric induces a topology @xmath87 on @xmath37 _",
    "( so , by definition , it follows that @xmath88 is a metrizable topological space ) .",
    "let @xmath89 be the group of affine transformations of @xmath90 given by @xmath91 where @xmath92 and @xmath61 .",
    "we say that two delzant polytopes @xmath93 and @xmath94 are _",
    "@xmath95-equivalent _ if there exists @xmath96 such that @xmath97 .",
    "let @xmath98 be the moduli space of delzant polytopes relative to @xmath95-equivalence ; we endow this space with the quotient topology induced by the projection map @xmath99    as we shall see in section [ stm ] , there exists a bijection @xmath100 ( in fact , it is induced by ( [ map ] ) ) ; thus @xmath73 is also a topological space , with topology @xmath101 induced by @xmath102 .",
    "_ we denote this topological space by @xmath103 .",
    "_      let @xmath104 be the @xmath105-algebra of borel sets of @xmath90 , the map @xmath106 be the lebesgue measure on @xmath90 , and @xmath107 the subset of borel sets with finite lebesgue measure .",
    "define @xmath108 where @xmath109 denotes the characteristic function of @xmath110 .",
    "this extends the distance function defined above on @xmath83 , but it is _ not _ a metric on @xmath111 . identifying the sets @xmath112 for which @xmath113 , we obtain a metric on the resulting quotient space of @xmath111 ( see section [ subsection : metric ] for details ) .",
    "let @xmath114 be the space of convex compact subsets of @xmath115 with positive lebesgue measure , @xmath116 the empty set , and @xmath117 then @xmath118 equipped with the distance function @xmath119 in ( [ first ] ) is a metric space .",
    "we prove the following theorem .",
    "[ key ] let @xmath37 and @xmath73 be the moduli spaces of toric four - dimensional manifolds , under isomorphisms and equivariant isomorphisms , respectively .",
    "then :    * @xmath103 is path - connected ; * @xmath86 is neither locally compact nor a complete metric space .",
    "its completion can be identified with the metric space @xmath120 in the following sense : identifying @xmath86 with @xmath121 via ( [ map ] ) , the completion of @xmath122 is @xmath120 .",
    "metric spaces are tychonoff ( that is , completely regular and hausdorff ) , therefore @xmath37 is tychonoff .",
    "the stone - ech compactification @xcite can be applied to tychonoff spaces .",
    "the stone - ech compactification , in general , gives rise to a compactified space which is hausdorff and normal .",
    "hence @xmath37 admits a hausdorff compactification .",
    "theorem [ key ] positively answers the case @xmath123 of problem 2.42 in @xcite .",
    "we do not know if the analogous statement to theorem [ key ] holds in dimensions greater than or equal to six .",
    "note that the constructions of the moduli spaces @xmath37 and @xmath73 do not depend on dimension .",
    "in section [ sec : dp ] we introduce the topological spaces we are going to work with , involving delzant polytopes and symplectic toric manifolds , under certain equivalence relations .",
    "the ingredient that allows us to relate these two categories of spaces is the delzant classification theorem ( theorem [ theo : delzant ] ) .",
    "section [ sec : conn ] starts with a detailed analysis of how to construct delzant polygons ( i.e. , polytopes of dimension @xmath124 ) following a simple recursive procedure presented in @xcite .",
    "this recipe is a main technical tool for the present paper ; no such method is known for polytopes of dimension greater than or equal to three .",
    "the remainder of this section and section [ sec : compl ] are devoted to proving the path - connectedness and metric properties of the space of delzant polygons ( or rather , a natural quotient of it ) ; the main theorem of the paper is implied by the results proven in these sections .",
    "finally , in section [ sec : problems ] , several open problems are presented .",
    "appendix [ sec : appendix ] contains a brief review of the polytope terms and results we use in the paper .",
    "we would like to thank the anonymous referee who made many useful comments and clarifications which have significantly improved an earlier version of the paper .",
    "ap is grateful to helmut hofer for discussions and support .",
    "he also thanks isabella novik for discussions concerning general polytope theory , and problem [ p30 ] , during a visit to the university of washington in 2010 .",
    "the authors are also grateful to victor guillemin and allen knutson for helpful advice .",
    "in this paper we are interested only in convex full dimensional polytopes , which we will simply call polytopes .",
    "we refer to appendix [ sec : appendix ] for the basic terminology and results on polytopes .",
    "[ del 2 ] ( following @xcite ) a convex polytope @xmath126 in @xmath90 is a _ delzant polytope _ if it is simple , rational and smooth :    * @xmath126 is _ simple _ if there are exactly @xmath6 edges meeting at each vertex @xmath127 ; * @xmath126 is _ rational _ if for every vertex @xmath127 , the edges meeting at @xmath128 are of the form @xmath129 , where @xmath130 and @xmath131 ; * a vertex @xmath127 is _ smooth _ if the edges meeting at @xmath128 are of the form @xmath132 , @xmath130 , where the vectors @xmath133 can be chosen to be a @xmath134 basis of @xmath135 .",
    "@xmath126 is _ smooth _ if every vertex @xmath127 is smooth .",

    "first of all , note that the intuitive paths from a delzant polygon @xmath247 to a translation of @xmath247 or a scaling of @xmath247 by a positive factor ( or a composition of the two ) are clearly continuous with respect to the topology induced by @xmath119 .",
    "furthermore , if @xmath248 then the entire path also lies in @xmath238 .",
    "the same holds when moving an edge parallel to itself without changing the total number of edges ( see figure [ moving edge ] ) .",
    "=    in particular , all delzant triangles @xmath249 are connected by a path in @xmath238 and so are the hirzebruch trapezoids @xmath215 , for each fixed @xmath250 .",

    "in this section we prove theorem [ key ] ( b ) . by the isomorphism , it suffices to study the topological properties of @xmath121 .",
    "let @xmath268 be the metric space introduced in section [ subsection : metric ] .",
    "the space @xmath121 is not complete .",
    "we prove that @xmath121 is not complete , by giving an example of a cauchy sequence in @xmath121 which converges in @xmath268 whose limit is not a smooth polytope , hence not in @xmath83 . for @xmath269 consider the hirzebruch surface @xmath215 , and note that we can rewrite @xmath224 as @xmath270 where @xmath64 is the length of the top facet .",
    "then , the sequence @xmath271 is cauchy , but its limit is a right angle triangle that is not delzant ( see figure [ limit ] ) .",
    "@xmath267    note that @xmath272 is also non - compact , since compact metric spaces are automatically complete .",
    "=   is not smooth.,title=\"fig:\",width=192 ]    let @xmath273 be the space of convex compact subsets of @xmath115 with positive lebesgue measure .",
    "note that if @xmath274 and @xmath113 then @xmath143 , and so @xmath119 is a metric on @xmath114 .",
    "the same observations hold for @xmath275 , the space of convex 2-dimensional polygons in @xmath115 , and @xmath276 , the space of rational convex 2-dimensional polygons in @xmath115 ( see definition [ del 2 ] ) .",
    "we have the following inclusions of metric spaces : @xmath277    as we will see in the proof of theorem [ prop : completion ] , all these inclusions are dense .",
    "let @xmath116 be the empty set , which clearly has zero lebesgue measure , and define @xmath278 thus @xmath279 and @xmath120 is a metric space .",
    "observe that @xmath280 , where the inclusion is a continuous map of metric spaces . with a similar argument    as before , we have the inclusions of metric spaces : @xmath281    we will prove in theorem [ c complete ] that @xmath120 is complete . to do this , we need the following lemma .    [ convex ] let @xmath282 be convex and non - bounded . if @xmath283 , then @xmath284 .",
    "consider two points @xmath285 .",
    "by convexity of @xmath286 , the straight line segment @xmath287 connecting @xmath288 to @xmath289 is contained in @xmath286 . since @xmath283 , there exists a point @xmath290 not collinear to @xmath288 and @xmath289 .",
    "hence the whole triangle @xmath291 is contained in @xmath286 .",

    "[ lemma : resolving ] let @xmath126 be a simple rational polytope in @xmath115 that fails to be smooth only at one vertex @xmath288 : the primitive vectors @xmath339 which direct the edges at @xmath288 do not form a @xmath134-basis of @xmath340 . then there is a simple rational polytope @xmath341 with at most @xmath342|-1 $ ] more edges than @xmath126 that is a smooth polytope and is equal to @xmath126 except in a neighborhood of @xmath288 .",
    "let @xmath343 and @xmath344 .",
    "we claim that there is always a matrix @xmath345 and @xmath346 , a primitive vector , such that @xmath347= \\left [ \\begin{array}{cc } 1 & \\alpha_0 \\\\ 0 & \\alpha_1 \\end{array } \\right].\\ ] ] if we set @xmath348|$ ] , the claim is equivalent to being able to solve the following for @xmath349 : @xmath350 note also that @xmath351 mod @xmath352 , for otherwise it would contradict that @xmath353 is primitive .",
    "the primitive vectors directing the edges of the polygon @xmath354 at the non - smooth vertex @xmath355 are @xmath356 and @xmath353 .",
    "we can additionally do a shear transformation via a matrix of the form @xmath357\\ ] ] and obtain a @xmath358-equivalent polygon @xmath359 for which the non - smooth vertex @xmath360 has edge directing vectors @xmath356 and @xmath361 where @xmath362 .",
    "we now create a new vertical edge on the polygon @xmath359 as close to the vertex @xmath360 as desired , thereby eliminating that vertex . call this new polygon @xmath93 .",
    "of the two vertices at the endpoints of this new edge , one is clearly smooth : the one with edge directing vectors @xmath356 and @xmath363 .",
    "the other vertex has edge directing vectors @xmath364 and @xmath361 and is smooth if and only if @xmath365=\\alpha_2=1.\\ ] ] if this second vertex is smooth , the desired polygon @xmath341 is @xmath366 otherwise , the process continues : let @xmath367 be the matrix @xmath368.\\ ] ] then the polygon @xmath369 is smooth except at one vertex @xmath370 , which has edge directing vectors @xmath371 and @xmath372 . as before , we can apply a shear transformation to obtain @xmath373 such that the edge directing vectors at the non - smooth vertex @xmath374 are of the form @xmath356 and @xmath375 with @xmath376 . proceeding exactly as before",
    ", we create a new vertical edge on the polygon @xmath373 as close to the vertex @xmath374 as desired , thereby eliminating it .",
    "call this new polygon @xmath94 . of the two vertices at the endpoints of the new edge ,",
    "the one with edge directing vectors @xmath363 and @xmath356 is clearly smooth , the other one has edge directing vectors @xmath364 and @xmath375 and is smooth if and only if @xmath377 .",
    "if that is so , the desired polygon @xmath341 is @xmath378 otherwise we repeat the process .    because @xmath379 is a strictly decreasing sequence of non - negative integers",
    ", it will reach @xmath160 in at most @xmath380 steps , thus terminating the process and producing @xmath341 with at most @xmath380 more edges than @xmath126 .",
    "this proves the statement in the lemma .",
    "@xmath267    [",
    "remark : resolving ] note that the process described in the proof of lemma [ lemma : resolving ] does not rely on @xmath126 being smooth at all vertices other than @xmath288 .",
    "in fact , the result holds for any simple rational non - smooth polytope @xmath126 , with any number of non - smooth vertices , except that the number of extra edges will be @xmath381 |-1   \\right),\\ ] ] where the @xmath382s are the non - smooth vertices of @xmath126 .",
    "the new polytope @xmath341 is equal to @xmath126 except in neighborhoods of the vertices @xmath382 that can be made as small as desired .",
    "now we are ready to prove the main theorem of this section .",
    "[ prop : completion ] the completion of @xmath121 is @xmath120 .    recall the metric space inclusions @xmath277 we shall prove that the completion of @xmath121 contains @xmath383 , that the completion of @xmath383 contains @xmath384 , and that the completion of @xmath384 contains @xmath299 .",
    "then by theorem [ c complete ] the conclusion follows .",
    "* a. ) * _ the completion of @xmath121 contains @xmath383 . _ because @xmath119 is a metric on @xmath276 that coincides with the given metric on @xmath83 , in order to prove that the completion of @xmath83 contains @xmath276 it suffices to show that for each @xmath385 there exists a polygon in @xmath83 as close to @xmath126 as desired , relative to the metric @xmath119 .",
    "lemma [ lemma : resolving ] and , in particular remark [ remark : resolving ] , guarantee that this is so .",
    "* b. ) * _ the completion of @xmath383 contains @xmath384 . _ because @xmath119 is a metric on @xmath275 that coincides with the given metric on @xmath276 , in order to prove that the completion of @xmath383 contains @xmath384 it suffices to show that for each @xmath386 there exists a polygon @xmath387 as close to @xmath126 as desired , relative to the metric @xmath119 .",
    "this rational polygon @xmath388 can be obtained by approximating the irrational slopes of the edges of @xmath126 by rational numbers and choosing for directing vectors of the edges the corresponding lattice vectors , and also by changing the vertex points accordingly .",
    "this way , we can make the symmetric difference between the original polygon @xmath126 and the rational polygon @xmath388 be contained in a @xmath196-ball of the edges of @xmath126 , the area of which can be made as small as needed by making @xmath389 small enough .    *",
    "c. ) * _ the completion of @xmath384 contains @xmath299 . _ because @xmath119 is a metric on @xmath114 that coincides with the given metric on @xmath275 , in order to prove that the completion of @xmath384 contains @xmath299 it suffices to show that for each @xmath390 there exists a polygon @xmath391 as close to @xmath292 as desired , relative to the metric @xmath119 . in order to do this ,",
    "observe that given a compact convex set @xmath392 and @xmath393 , there exists a collection of disjoint rectangles @xmath394 contained in @xmath292 such that @xmath395 let @xmath94 be the convex hull of @xmath396\\times [ c_i , d_i]$ ] .",
    "since @xmath292 is convex , we have @xmath397 and hence @xmath398 which proves the claim .",
    "@xmath267    the space @xmath121 is not locally compact .    to prove that @xmath121 is not locally compact ,",
    "we show that the closure of any open ball @xmath399 is not compact in @xmath121 . for each fixed @xmath196 ,",
    "let @xmath400 be an irrational number , and let @xmath401 be the polygon in figure [ irr ] .",
    "note that @xmath402 . by a triangle inequality argument it is easy to see that @xmath403 because @xmath121 is dense in @xmath384 ( see the proof of theorem [ prop : completion ] ) , there exists a sequence of delzant polygons @xmath404 that converges to @xmath401 in @xmath384 .",
    "thus any subsequence of @xmath405 also converges to @xmath401 in @xmath384 , and hence does not converge in @xmath121 .",
    "this proves that the closure of @xmath406 in @xmath83 is not compact .",
    "@xmath267    = .,title=\"fig:\",width=144 ]    [ hausdorff ] there is another metric commonly used on @xmath114 , namely the _ hausdorff metric _ @xmath407 ( see @xcite ) . given two elements @xmath274",
    ", we define @xmath408 as proved in @xcite , the metrics @xmath119 and @xmath409 are equivalent on @xmath114 , and consequently all the topological properties proved for @xmath299 and @xmath121 also hold for @xmath410 and @xmath411",
    ". we chose to work with @xmath119 because on @xmath83 this is related to the duistermaat - heckman measure ( see remark [ dh ] ) .",
    "other moduli spaces of polygons have been studied , for example , in @xcite by hausmann and knutson and in @xcite by kapovich and millson .",
    "the former focuses on the space of polygons in @xmath412 with a fixed number of edges up to translations and positive homotheties , whereas the latter studies the space of polygons in @xmath115 with fixed side lengths up to orientation preserving isometries .",
    "however these different contexts completely change the flavor of the topological problem .",
    "theorem [ key ] leads to further questions ( not directly related among themselves ) .",
    "first of all , we recall that symplectic toric manifolds are always khler ( see @xcite ) . besides the spaces we introduced",
    ", it would be interesting to study the topological properties of the following :    * @xmath413 , where @xmath414 corresponds to rescaling the symplectic form , with the quotient topology .",
    "this corresponds to considering the space @xmath415 .",
    "* @xmath416 , where we also identify the khler manifolds @xmath2 and @xmath417 if the cohomology classes of their khler forms live in the same connected component of the khler cone .",
    "this question attempts to make more explicit the relation between the completion at the level of polytopes with the completion at the level of manifolds given in theorem [ key ] .",
    "view @xmath37 as a subset of the set of ( all ) integrable systems on symplectic @xmath10-manifolds @xmath418 the map @xmath419 given by @xmath420 extends ( [ map ] ) . what can one say about the intersection @xmath421 even though in this question @xmath422 is assumed smooth ( because integrable systems @xmath423 are usually required to be everywhere smooth ) , the case when @xmath422 is just continuous on @xmath7 and smooth on an open dense subset of @xmath7 is also interesting .",
    "also , it would be interesting to investigate under which conditions @xmath422 integrates to a @xmath424-action on ( an open dense subset of ) @xmath7 .",
    "( see , for example , ( * ? ? ?",
    "* proposition 2.12 ) . )    a different but related approach to the same problem is to enlarge the category of objects by relaxing the smoothness condition on the polytope .",
    "for example , from the work of lerman and tolman in @xcite , we know that any rational convex polytope is the momentum map image of a symplectic toric orbifold",
    ". however we do not know of a similar identification for generic convex compact subsets of @xmath115 .",
    "this paper addresses the case @xmath123 of problem 2.42 in @xcite .",
    "we do not have results on the higher dimensional case @xmath425 .",
    "[ p30 ] consider the maximal density function @xmath426\\ ] ] which assigns to a symplectic toric manifold its maximal density by equivariantly embedded symplectic balls of varying radii ( see ( * ? ? ?",
    "* definition 2.4 ) ) .",
    "the function is most interesting when considered on @xmath413 , where @xmath414 corresponds to rescaling the symplectic form ( since rescaling the symplectic form rescales the polytope and does not change the density ) .",
    "this paper gives a quotient topology on @xmath413 .",
    "with respect to this topology , where is @xmath427 continuous ?",
    "@xmath427 is an interesting map even if one disregards topology , for instance the fiber over @xmath160 consists of 2 points , @xmath428 , and @xmath429 ( proven in ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem 1.7 ) ) with scaled symplectic forms , but for any other @xmath430 the fiber is uncountable ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorems 1.2 , 1.3 )",
    ".    it would be interesting to define a torus action on the moduli spaces @xmath37 or @xmath73 .",
    "similarly for a symplectic form ( e.g. , @xcite ) .",
    "if one has both a torus action and a symplectic form , then one can formulate a notion of hamiltonian action and momentum map , and study connectivity and convexity properties of the image ( see for instance @xcite ) .",
    "compute the topological invariants ( fundamental group , higher homotopy groups , cohomology groups , etc . ) of the path - connected space @xmath73 .",
    "some preliminary questions in this direction are :    * find non - trivial loop classes in @xmath431 ; * find non - trivial cohomology classes in @xmath432 .    in view of the constructions of this paper",
    ", one should be able to compute these classes with the aid of the concrete description of the polytope space .",
    "this problem is a particular case of ( * ? ? ?",
    "* problem 2.46 ) .",
    "let @xmath433 be a finite dimensional real vector space .",
    "a _ convex polytope _ @xmath434 in @xmath433 is the closed convex hull of a finite set @xmath435 , i.e. , the smallest convex set containing @xmath434 or , equivalently , @xmath436 , \\;\\sum_{i=1}^n a_i = 1 \\right\\}\\right .. \\ ] ] the _ dimension _ of @xmath437 is the dimension of the vector space @xmath438 .",
    "a polytope is _ full dimensional _ if its dimension equals the dimension of @xmath433 .",
    "note that the definition implies that a convex polytope is a compact subset of @xmath433 .",
    "an _ extreme point _ of a convex subset @xmath439 is a point of @xmath292 which does not lie in any open line segment joining two points of @xmath292 .",
    "thus , a convex polytope is the closed convex hull of its extreme points ( by the krein - milman theorem @xcite ) called _ vertices_. in particular , the set of vertices is contained in @xmath435 .",
    "clearly , there are infinitely many descriptions of the same polytope as a closed convex hull of a finite set of points . however , the description of a polytope as the convex hull of its vertices is minimal and unique .",
    "there is another description of convex polytopes in terms of intersections of half - spaces .",
    "let @xmath440 be the dual of @xmath433 and denote by @xmath441 the natural non - degenerate duality pairing .",
    "the _ positive ( negative ) half - space _ defined by @xmath442 and @xmath443 is defined by @xmath444 traditionally , in the theory of convex polytopes , the half spaces are chosen to be of the form @xmath445 . with these definitions ,",
    "a convex polytope is given as a finite intersection of half - spaces .",
    "as for the convex hull representation , there are infinitely many representations of the same convex polytope as a finite intersection of half - spaces , but unlike it , a distinguished one that is minimal exists only for full dimensional polytopes , we will describe it in the next paragraph .    a _ face _ of a convex polytope is an intersection with a half - space satisfying the following condition : the boundary of the half - space does not contain any interior point of the polytope .",
    "thus the faces of a convex polytope are themselves polytopes ( and hence compact sets ) .",
    "let @xmath446 be the dimension of a convex polytope .",
    "then the whole polytope is the unique @xmath446-dimensional face , or _ body _ , the @xmath447-dimensional faces are called _ facets _ , the @xmath160-dimensional faces are the _ edges _ , and the @xmath448-dimensional faces are the vertices of the polytope . if the convex polytope is full - dimensional , its minimal and unique description as an intersection of half - spaces is given when the boundary of those half - spaces contain the facets ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> we construct a distance on the moduli space of symplectic toric manifolds of dimension four . </S>",
    "<S> then we study some basic topological properties of this space , in particular , path - connectedness , compactness , and completeness . </S>",
    "<S> the construction of the distance is related to the duistermaat - heckman measure and the hausdorff metric . </S>",
    "<S> while the moduli space , its topology and metric , may be constructed in any dimension , the tools we use in the proofs are four - dimensional , and hence so is our main result . </S>"
  ]
}
